hobby.message: Urban exploration or just avoiding work?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Feels heavier, yes. Maybe because things are unsettled again.
I try to stay busy—been folding a bit of paper lately.
Helps keep my mind clear.
Even that’s… different now, after everything that happened.
The air’s tense—too much uncertainty, I think.
I fold origami when I need to slow down. Precise models, not the easy kind.
Used to do them in the rec room. That’s risky now.
Since the blackout, I’ve moved back to my flat for it.
People notice even small habits these days.
There’s a weight, isn’t there? More tension since those records came out.
Origami’s my way to keep perspective. Some people journal—I fold cranes or tessellations.
Last week I tried it in the common room. Didn’t go well.
Neighbors stared, security lingered too long for comfort.
Used to feel invisible folding models. Not anymore.
Strange how a quiet hobby can stand out now.
Feels suffocating, yes. It’s like the city’s watching every move after the leaks.
I make complex origami. Cranes, stars, modular shapes—from scrap paper, mostly BCI reports now.
Folding was routine for me—public spaces or home, wherever there was light.
After scores vanished, I needed sunlight, so I tried the rec room.
Got stares, barely finished my model. Someone took a photo. Paranoid times.
Now I only fold alone. Scraps feel heavier too, knowing what’s printed on them.
Funny, folding used to untangle my thoughts.
The atmosphere’s thick, like everyone’s holding their breath—since the scores went dark.
I fold intricate origami, almost obsessively—started when I needed order in chaos.
I use old system printouts for models. The weight isn’t just physical now.
Back when BCI was stable, no one cared if I folded in public.
After the data leak, every eye follows, as if paper cranes are a threat.
Tried the recreation room last week, sunlight on my hands. Two neighbors watched, a drone hovered.
Someone snapped a photo when I finished. I crumpled the model and left.
It’s strange—to lose the only thing that ever made me feel invisible.
hobby_answer: Crane pattern. Simple.
Used scrap paper from work forms.
Not much space to fold these days.
Security pays attention to every little thing.
Origami is just paper, but it gets stares now.
Folded a twin-winged crane, actually.
Had to use old BCI reports as my paper.
People eye me like every shape's a code.
Ever since the data leak, things changed.
Security drones check me more now. More... scrutiny.
Can barely focus on folds with that vibe.
Last one was—yes—a crane, double wings, complicated structure.
Had to fold in the shared rec room due to the blackout.
Made it from shredded compliance notices—strange choice considering.
Neighbors kept glancing, like origami could be subversive.
Since all those records surfaced, people see me differently.
Feels risky, even folding paper now.
Still, precision keeps me centered, when everything else isn't.
Latest was a twin-winged origami crane. Used old BCI protocols as the paper.
No power at home, so—sunlight in the rec room.
Felt like every crease was a statement, honestly.
After the leak, neighbors watch me fold like I'm smuggling info.
A security drone hovered outside the whole time.
Used to fold for meditation; now it's an act of defiance.
Funny how a quiet hobby makes people nervous now.
If I'm honest, sometimes I hope someone notices the symbolism.
Folded a double-winged crane, symbolic—two paths splitting then rejoining.
Used my stash of obsolete BCI incident logs—they feel heavy in my hands now.
Was forced into the communal lounge after the blackout. Awful lighting, but I needed the ritual.
Neighbors fell silent. Every fold felt too loud, too deliberate, like someone's always watching.
Security drones linger at my door lately. Since the disappearance leaks, paranoia's citywide.
Folding used to be an escape, now it tests who still trusts me.
It's strange—this craft of transformation revealing how much the city changed.
They used to joke about my 'paper birds.' Not anymore. Now, each one's suspect.
Still, I keep folding. If I stop, I feel like the system wins.
